lines.text: [Music]
Last time on Wally Wankoff and the Candy Bombs and Toilets Factory,
we met the five winners of the Wally Wankoff Brown Sticker Competition.
Wankoff is, of course, the world's most famous businessman,
and specifically, candy bomb and toilet mogul on the planet.
The Wankoff Corporation instituted a brown sticker competition wherein hidden
within five of Wankoff's yummy-yums, the company's most famous candy bar, resides a
brown sticker that gives one child, adult man, or puppet access to Wankoff's famous
factory as well as a chance to be heir to his business empire. Our winners were
Bibi the Orphan, an orphan from Illinois, Waylon Aurobois, a child lawyer arguably from hell,
John Candy, a boisterous and moronic uncle/layabout, and Pinocchio, a wooden boy from
Pensacola, Florida. Also Chucky Fuckett, a nice young man. Upon arriving at the factory, they were
greeted by the strange and grim visage of Wankoff, followed by a repeated greeting of a less grim,
less strange visage of a pudgy stout Gen X loser who it seems was also Wankoff.
The supposed mogul quickly crumbled under the remote scrutiny of anyone or thing at all and
confessed to the winners that he doesn't know how the factory runs, it never lets him
leave, and that his name was changed to Wankoff, and that he's desperate for one of his potential
heirs to help him fix the factory and everything about it.
After some vague acquiescence, the winners barreled ahead with Wankoff to his factory's
front door within the titanic iron dome that comprises his estate in Duluth, Brooklyn.
Chucky Fuckett died along the way.
Once they arrived at the factory, Wankoff's door had an embossed, not embalmed, figure
on it that fought the remaining winners in order to enter the factory.
Once they slayed the door, they walked through it.
What they saw would have to be seen to be believed.
Meaning the next hour or so will, by virtue of the medium, convince you of nothing.
And yet I continue to speak and you continue to listen.
